user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_probe_driver:
```c
static int metal_linux_probe_driver(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				    struct linux_driver *ldrv)
{
	char command[256];
	int ret;

	ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);

	/* Try probing the module and then open the driver. */
	if (!ldrv->sdrv) {
		ret = snprintf(command, sizeof(command),
			       "modprobe %s > /dev/null 2>&1", ldrv->mod_name);
		if (ret >= (int)sizeof(command))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		ret = system(command);
		if (ret < 0) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
				  "%s: executing system command '%s' failed.\n",
				  __func__, command);
		}
		ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);
	}

	/* Try sudo probing the module and then open the driver. */
	if (!ldrv->sdrv) {
		ret = snprintf(command, sizeof(command),
			       "sudo modprobe %s > /dev/null 2>&1", ldrv->mod_name);
		if (ret >= (int)sizeof(command))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		ret = system(command);
		if (ret < 0) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
				  "%s: executing system command '%s' failed.\n",
				  __func__, command);
		}
		ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);
	}

	/* If all else fails... */
	return ldrv->sdrv ? 0 : -ENODEV;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_probe_driver:
static int metal_linux_probe_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;
	int ret, error = -ENODEV;

	lbus->sbus = sysfs_open_bus(lbus->bus_name);
	if (!lbus->sbus)
		return -ENODEV;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		ret = metal_linux_probe_driver(lbus, ldrv);
		/* Clear the error if any driver is available */
		if (!ret)
			error = ret;
	}

	if (error) {
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);
		return error;
	}

	error = metal_linux_register_bus(lbus);
	if (error)
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);

	return error;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I focused on code fragments that introduce early unconditional returns (return -EOVERFLOW, return -ENODEV, return error) or final return expressions that determine overall success. These are the places most likely to create unreachable code paths that need investigation under MISRA C Rule 2.1 (unreachable code). Other statements in the provided functions (calls to sysfs_open_driver/sysfs_open_bus, system(), metal_log(), assignment to ldrv->sdrv, the for_each_linux_driver loop body and the subsequent call to metal_linux_register_bus) do not contain unconditional returns, infinite loops, or constant-condition branches in the shown code and therefore do not by themselves create statically unreachable code; they are executed conditionally at runtime and are reachable depending on inputs/return values. Consequently they do not need further investigation for unreachable-code concerns based on the snippets provided.
